## The Bug

After the nisaba refactor, response method signatures changed:

**Old:**
```python
_success_response(data, start_time, warnings=...)
_error_response(error, start_time, ...)
```

**New:**
```python
_success_response(data, warnings=None, metadata=None)
_error_response(error, severity=..., recovery_hint=..., context=...)
```

All nabu tools were still calling with `start_time` as the second parameter ‚Üí caused it to be passed as `warnings` ‚Üí AttributeError when something expected a list and called `.value` on the float.

    17‚Üí    
    18‚Üí    def format(self, data: Dict[str, Any],) -> str:
    19‚Üí        """Format find_clones output in compact style."""
    20‚Üí        lines = []
    21‚Üí        
    22‚Üí        # Extract data
    23‚Üí        clone_pairs = data.get("clone_pairs", [])
    24‚Üí        summary = data.get("summary", {})
    25‚Üí        metadata = data.get("metadata", {})
    26‚Üí        clone_clusters = data.get("clone_clusters", [])
    27‚Üí        
    28‚Üí        # Header
    29‚Üí        lines.append("# Clone Detection")
    30‚Üí        lines.append("")
    31‚Üí        
    32‚Üí        # Summary - compact format
    33‚Üí        lines.append("## Summary")
    34‚Üí        total_pairs = summary.get("total_pairs", 0)
    35‚Üí        by_severity = summary.get("by_severity", {})
    36‚Üí        affected_files = summary.get("affected_files", 0)
    37‚Üí        loc_reduction = summary.get("potential_loc_reduction", 0)
    38‚Üí        
    39‚Üí        critical = by_severity.get("CRITICAL", 0)
    40‚Üí        high = by_severity.get("HIGH", 0)
    41‚Üí        medium = by_severity.get("MEDIUM", 0)
    42‚Üí        
    43‚Üí        lines.append(f"Total pairs: {total_pairs} | CRITICAL: {critical}, HIGH: {high}, MEDIUM: {medium}")
    44‚Üí        lines.append(f"Affected files: {affected_files} | Potential LOC reduction: {loc_reduction}")
    45‚Üí        lines.append("")
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí        # Clone Clusters - stratified view
    48‚Üí        if clone_clusters:
    49‚Üí            lines.append("## Clone Clusters")
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí            multi_way = [c for c in clone_clusters if c["cluster_type"] == "multi-way"]
    52‚Üí            pairwise = [c for c in clone_clusters if c["cluster_type"] == "pairwise"]
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí            if multi_way:
    55‚Üí                lines.append("")
    56‚Üí                multi_pairs = sum(c["pair_count"] for c in multi_way)
    57‚Üí                lines.append(f"**Multi-way clusters ({len(multi_way)} clusters, {multi_pairs} pairs):**")
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí                for cluster in multi_way[:10]:  # Show top 10 multi-way
    60‚Üí                    # Get representative function name (most common)
    61‚Üí                    func_names = cluster["function_names"]
    62‚Üí                    representative_name = func_names[0] if len(func_names) == 1 else f"{func_names[0]} (+{len(func_names)-1} variants)"
    63‚Üí
    64‚Üí                    nodes = cluster["node_count"]
    65‚Üí                    pairs = cluster["pair_count"]
    66‚Üí                    avg_sim = cluster["avg_similarity"]
    67‚Üí                    loc = cluster["total_loc"]
    68‚Üí
    69‚Üí                    lines.append(f"‚îú‚îÄ {representative_name}: {nodes} nodes, {pairs} pairs, avg {avg_sim:.3f} sim - {loc} LOC")
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí            if pairwise:
    72‚Üí                lines.append("")
    73‚Üí                lines.append(f"**Pairwise clones ({len(pairwise)} isolated pairs):**")
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí                for cluster in pairwise[:5]:  # Show top 5 pairwise
    76‚Üí                    pair = cluster["pairs"][0]  # Each pairwise cluster has exactly 1 pair
    77‚Üí                    func1_name = pair["function_1"]["name"]
    78‚Üí                    func2_name = pair["function_2"]["name"]
    79‚Üí                    similarity = pair["similarity"]
    80‚Üí
    81‚Üí                    # Show different names or indicate same name
    82‚Üí                    if func1_name == func2_name:
    83‚Üí                        desc = func1_name
    84‚Üí                    else:
    85‚Üí                        desc = f"{func1_name} / {func2_name}"
    86‚Üí
    87‚Üí                    lines.append(f"‚îú‚îÄ {desc}: {similarity:.4f} similarity")
    88‚Üí
    89‚Üí            lines.append("")
    90‚Üí
    91‚Üí        # Clone pairs - table format with severity indicators
    92‚Üí        lines.append("## Clone Pairs")
    93‚Üí        if clone_pairs:
    94‚Üí            lines.append("| Severity | Function 1 | Function 2 | Similarity | Recommendation |")
    95‚Üí            lines.append("|----------|------------|------------|------------|----------------|")
    96‚Üí            for pair in clone_pairs:
    97‚Üí                func1 = pair.get("function_1", {})
    98‚Üí                func2 = pair.get("function_2", {})
    99‚Üí                similarity = pair.get("similarity", 0.0)
   100‚Üí                severity = pair.get("severity", "UNKNOWN")
   101‚Üí                recommendation = pair.get("recommendation", "")
   102‚Üí                
   103‚Üí                func1_name = func1.get("name", "unknown")
   104‚Üí                func1_loc = func1.get("location", "unknown")
   105‚Üí                func1_lines = func1.get("line_count", 0)
   106‚Üí                
   107‚Üí                func2_name = func2.get("name", "unknown")
   108‚Üí                func2_loc = func2.get("location", "unknown")
   109‚Üí                func2_lines = func2.get("line_count", 0)
   110‚Üí                
   111‚Üí                func1_desc = f"{func1_name} ({func1_loc}, {func1_lines} LOC)"
   112‚Üí                func2_desc = f"{func2_name} ({func2_loc}, {func2_lines} LOC)"
   113‚Üí                
   114‚Üí                lines.append(f"| {severity} | {func1_desc} | {func2_desc} | {similarity:.4f} | {recommendation} |")
   115‚Üí        else:
   116‚Üí            lines.append("*(No clones found)*")
   117‚Üí        lines.append("")
   118‚Üí        
   119‚Üí        # Metadata - settings used
   120‚Üí        min_similarity = metadata.get("min_similarity", 0.0)
   121‚Üí        excluded_same_file = metadata.get("excluded_same_file", False)
   122‚Üí        min_function_size = metadata.get("min_function_size", 0)
   123‚Üí        
   124‚Üí        lines.append(f"Settings: min_similarity={min_similarity}, same_file_excluded={excluded_same_file}, min_function_size={min_function_size}")
   125‚Üí           
   126‚Üí        return "
".join(lines)

    37‚Üídef detect_regex_pattern(target: str) -> bool:
    38‚Üí    """
    39‚Üí    Detect if target string looks like a regex pattern.
    40‚Üí
    41‚Üí    Uses heuristics to identify common regex metacharacters and patterns.
    42‚Üí
    43‚Üí    Args:
    44‚Üí        target: String to analyze
    45‚Üí
    46‚Üí    Returns:
    47‚Üí        True if target appears to be a regex pattern, False otherwise
    48‚Üí
    49‚Üí    Examples:
    50‚Üí        >>> detect_regex_pattern("MyClass")
    51‚Üí        False
    52‚Üí        >>> detect_regex_pattern(".*Tool$")
    53‚Üí        True
    54‚Üí        >>> detect_regex_pattern("(Foo|Bar|Baz)")
    55‚Üí        True
    56‚Üí    """
    57‚Üí    regex_indicators = [
    58‚Üí        '.*', '.+', '|', '^', '$',
    59‚Üí        '\(', '\)', '\[', '\]',
    60‚Üí        '{', '}', '?', '+'
    61‚Üí    ]
    62‚Üí    return any(indicator in target for indicator in regex_indicators)
    63‚Üí
    64‚Üí
    65‚Üíclass NabuTool(BaseTool):
    66‚Üí    """
    67‚Üí    Nabu-specific MCP tool base class.
    68‚Üí
    69‚Üí    Extends BaseTool with nabu-specific features:
    70‚Üí    - Database manager access
    71‚Üí    - Incremental updater access
    72‚Üí    - Output formatters (markdown, json)
    73‚Üí    - Enhanced response builders
    74‚Üí    - Schema generation from docstrings
    75‚Üí
    76‚Üí    Each tool must implement:
    77‚Üí    - execute(**kwargs) -> Dict[str, Any]: The main tool logic
    78‚Üí    """
    79‚Üí
    80‚Üí    def __init__(self, factory: "NabuMCPFactory"):
    81‚Üí        """
    82‚Üí        Initialize tool with factory reference.
    83‚Üí
    84‚Üí        Args:
    85‚Üí            factory: The NabuMCPFactory that created this tool
    86‚Üí        """
    87‚Üí        super().__init__(factory)
    88‚Üí        self._output_format = "json"  # Nabu-specific: track requested output format
    89‚Üí
    90‚Üí    # Note: get_name_from_cls() and get_name() inherited from BaseTool
    91‚Üí
    92‚Üí    @classmethod
    93‚Üí    def nisaba(cls) -> bool:
    94‚Üí        """
    95‚Üí        Nabu tools are not nisaba-certified (they use ResponseBuilder formatting).
    96‚Üí
    97‚Üí        Returns:
    98‚Üí            False - nabu tools use custom response formatting
    99‚Üí        """
   100‚Üí        return False
   101‚Üí
   102‚Üí    # Agent access property (explicit pattern acknowledgment)
   103‚Üí    @property
   104‚Üí    def agent(self):
   105‚Üí        """
   106‚Üí        Access to NabuAgent for stateful resources.
   107‚Üí
   108‚Üí        The agent manages:
   109‚Üí        - Database managers (multi-codebase)
   110‚Üí        - Incremental updaters
   111‚Üí        - Auto-indexing
   112‚Üí        - Session tracking
   113‚Üí        - Workflow guidance
   114‚Üí
   115‚Üí        Returns:
   116‚Üí            NabuAgent instance
   117‚Üí        """
   118‚Üí        return self.factory.agent
   119‚Üí
   120‚Üí    # Nabu-specific: Database access properties
   121‚Üí    @property
   122‚Üí    def db_manager(self):
   123‚Üí        """
   124‚Üí        Access to database manager.
   125‚Üí        
   126‚Üí        Automatically uses the codebase from execution context if set,
   127‚Üí        otherwise falls back to active codebase.
   128‚Üí        """
   129‚Üí        # Check if we're in a codebase-specific execution context
   130‚Üí        context_codebase = _current_codebase_context.get()
   131‚Üí        
   132‚Üí        if context_codebase:
   133‚Üí            # Use context-specific database manager
   134‚Üí            return self.factory.db_managers.get(context_codebase, self.factory.db_manager)
   135‚Üí        
   136‚Üí        # Fall back to factory's current db_manager (active codebase)
   137‚Üí        return self.factory.db_manager
   138‚Üí
   139‚Üí    @property
   140‚Üí    def incremental_updater(self):
   141‚Üí        """
   142‚Üí        Access to incremental updater.
   143‚Üí        
   144‚Üí        Automatically uses the codebase from execution context if set,
   145‚Üí        otherwise falls back to active codebase.
   146‚Üí        """
   147‚Üí        # Check if we're in a codebase-specific execution context
   148‚Üí        context_codebase = _current_codebase_context.get()
   149‚Üí        
   150‚Üí        if context_codebase:
   151‚Üí            # Use context-specific incremental updater
   152‚Üí            return self.factory.incremental_updaters.get(context_codebase, self.factory.incremental_updater)
   153‚Üí        
   154‚Üí        # Fall back to factory's current incremental_updater (active codebase)
   155‚Üí        return self.factory.incremental_updater
   156‚Üí
   157‚Üí    def get_db_manager(self, codebase: Optional[str] = None):
   158‚Üí        """
   159‚Üí        Get database manager for specified codebase.
   160‚Üí        
   161‚Üí        Args:
   162‚Üí            codebase: Codebase name, or None to use active codebase
   163‚Üí            
   164‚Üí        Returns:
   165‚Üí            KuzuConnectionManager for the codebase
   166‚Üí            
   167‚Üí        Raises:
   168‚Üí            ValueError: If codebase not found
   169‚Üí        """
   170‚Üí        target = codebase or self.config.active_codebase
   171‚Üí        
   172‚Üí        if target not in self.factory.db_managers:
   173‚Üí            available = list(self.factory.db_managers.keys())
   174‚Üí            raise ValueError(
   175‚Üí                f"Codebase '{target}' not found. Available: {available}"
   176‚Üí            )
   177‚Üí        
   178‚Üí        return self.factory.db_managers[target]
   179‚Üí
   180‚Üí    def get_codebase_config(self, codebase: Optional[str] = None):
   181‚Üí        """
   182‚Üí        Get configuration for specified codebase.
   183‚Üí        
   184‚Üí        Args:
   185‚Üí            codebase: Codebase name, or None to use active codebase
   186‚Üí            
   187‚Üí        Returns:
   188‚Üí            CodebaseConfig for the codebase
   189‚Üí            
   190‚Üí        Raises:
   191‚Üí            ValueError: If codebase not found
   192‚Üí        """
   193‚Üí        target = codebase or self.config.active_codebase
   194‚Üí        
   195‚Üí        if target not in self.config.codebases:
   196‚Üí            available = list(self.config.codebases.keys())
   197‚Üí            raise ValueError(
   198‚Üí                f"Codebase '{target}' not found. Available: {available}"
   199‚Üí            )
   200‚Üí        
   201‚Üí        return self.config.codebases[target]
   202‚Üí
   203‚Üí    def _check_indexing_status(self, codebase: Optional[str] = None) -> Optional[Dict[str, Any]]:
   204‚Üí        """
   205‚Üí        Check if codebase is being indexed and return error response if so.
   206‚Üí
   207‚Üí        This method should be called at the start of execute() in tools that
   208‚Üí        require database access (search, query, skeleton, etc.).
   209‚Üí
   210‚Üí        Args:
   211‚Üí            codebase: Codebase to check, or None for active codebase
   212‚Üí
   213‚Üí        Returns:
   214‚Üí            Error response dict if indexing in progress or failed, None if ready
   215‚Üí        """
   216‚Üí        target = codebase or self.config.active_codebase
   217‚Üí
   218‚Üí        if not self.factory.auto_indexer:
   219‚Üí            return None  # No auto-indexer, skip check
   220‚Üí
   221‚Üí        from nabu.mcp.indexing import IndexingState
   222‚Üí        status = self.factory.auto_indexer.get_status(target)
   223‚Üí
   224‚Üí        if status.state in (IndexingState.UNINDEXED, IndexingState.QUEUED):
   225‚Üí            return self._error_response(
   226‚Üí                RuntimeError(f"Codebase '{target}' is queued for indexing"),
   227‚Üí                severity=ErrorSeverity.WARNING,
   228‚Üí                recovery_hint=(
   229‚Üí                    f"Database is being prepared. State: {status.state.value}. "
   230‚Üí                    "Check show_status() for progress."
   231‚Üí                )
   232‚Üí            )
   233‚Üí
   234‚Üí        if status.state == IndexingState.INDEXING:
   235‚Üí            elapsed = time.time() - status.started_at if status.started_at else 0
   236‚Üí            return self._error_response(
   237‚Üí                RuntimeError(f"Codebase '{target}' is currently being indexed"),
   238‚Üí                severity=ErrorSeverity.WARNING,
   239‚Üí                recovery_hint=(
   240‚Üí                    f"Indexing in progress ({elapsed:.1f}s elapsed). "
   241‚Üí                    "This may take several minutes for large codebases. "
   242‚Üí                    "Check show_status() for updates."
   243‚Üí                )
   244‚Üí            )
   245‚Üí
   246‚Üí        if status.state == IndexingState.ERROR:
   247‚Üí            return self._error_response(
   248‚Üí                RuntimeError(f"Codebase '{target}' indexing failed"),
   249‚Üí                severity=ErrorSeverity.ERROR,
   250‚Üí                recovery_hint=(
   251‚Üí                    f"Auto-indexing failed: {status.error_message}. "
   252‚Üí                    "Use rebuild_database() tool to retry manually."
   253‚Üí                )
   254‚Üí            )
   255‚Üí
   256‚Üí        # State is INDEXED - all good
   257‚Üí        return None
   258‚Üí
   259‚Üí    async def _resolve_frame(
   260‚Üí        self,
   261‚Üí        target: str,
   262‚Üí        frame_type: Optional[str] = None,
   263‚Üí        require_exact: bool = False,
   264‚Üí        is_regex: bool = False,
   265‚Üí        limit: int = 50
   266‚Üí    ) -> List[Dict[str, Any]]:
   267‚Üí        """
   268‚Üí        Unified frame resolution with intelligent matching and regex support.
   269‚Üí
   270‚Üí        Supports flexible input formats:
   271‚Üí        - Simple name: "MyClass" ‚Üí matches any frame with that name
   272‚Üí        - Hierarchical path: "utils/MyClass" or "MyClass/my_method"
   273‚Üí        - Qualified name: "nabu.mcp.utils.MyClass"
   274‚Üí        - Regex pattern (with is_regex=True): ".*Tool$" or "(Foo|Bar)Handler"
   275‚Üí
   276‚Üí        Args:
   277‚Üí            target: Frame identifier (name, qualified name, hierarchical path, or regex pattern)
   278‚Üí            frame_type: Optional frame type filter (e.g., "CLASS", "CALLABLE")
   279‚Üí            require_exact: If True, only exact qualified_name matches allowed (ignored if is_regex=True)
   280‚Üí            is_regex: If True, treat target as regex pattern and return multiple matches
   281‚Üí            limit: Maximum number of results to return (only applies when is_regex=True)
   282‚Üí
   283‚Üí        Returns:
   284‚Üí            List of frame data dicts. Returns single-element list for non-regex queries,
   285‚Üí            multiple elements for regex queries, or empty list if no matches found.
   286‚Üí        """
   287‚Üí        if not self.db_manager:
   288‚Üí            raise RuntimeError("Database manager not initialized - cannot resolve frames")
   289‚Üí
   290‚Üí        # ========== REGEX PATH ==========
   291‚Üí        if is_regex:
   292‚Üí            # Validate regex pattern
   293‚Üí            try:
   294‚Üí                regex_obj = re.compile(target)
   295‚Üí            except re.error as e:
   296‚Üí                self.logger().error(f"Invalid regex pattern '{target}': {e}")
   297‚Üí                return []
   298‚Üí
   299‚Üí            try:
   300‚Üí                # STRATEGY: Two-path approach (aligned with SearchTool._regex_search)
   301‚Üí                # PATH 1: Cypher native regex (fast, database-side filtering)
   302‚Üí                # PATH 2: Keyword extraction + Python regex (fallback for complex patterns)
   303‚Üí
   304‚Üí                results = []
   305‚Üí                result_ids = set()
   306‚Üí
   307‚Üí                # ========== PATH 1: Cypher Native Regex (Primary) ==========
   308‚Üí                # Escape single quotes for safe Cypher interpolation
   309‚Üí                escaped_pattern = target.replace("'", "\'")
   310‚Üí
   311‚Üí                cypher_query = f"""
   312‚Üí                MATCH (f:Frame)
   313‚Üí                WHERE f.name =~ '{escaped_pattern}'
   314‚Üí                   OR f.qualified_name =~ '{escaped_pattern}'
   315‚Üí                """
   316‚Üí
   317‚Üí                # Add frame type filter if specified
   318‚Üí                if frame_type:
   319‚Üí                    # Support both single type and pipe-separated list
   320‚Üí                    if '|' in frame_type:
   321‚Üí                        type_list = [t.strip() for t in frame_type.split('|')]
   322‚Üí                        type_list_str = str(type_list).replace("'", '"')  # Cypher uses double quotes
   323‚Üí                        cypher_query += f"
   AND f.type IN {type_list_str}"
   324‚Üí                    else:
   325‚Üí                        cypher_query += f"
   AND f.type = '{frame_type}'"
   326‚Üí
   327‚Üí                cypher_query += f"""
   328‚Üí                RETURN f.id as id, f.type as type, f.name as name,
   329‚Üí                       f.qualified_name as qualified_name,
   330‚Üí                       f.file_path as file_path, f.start_line as start_line,
   331‚Üí                       f.end_line as end_line, f.language as language,
   332‚Üí                       f.instance_fields as instance_fields, f.static_fields as static_fields,
   333‚Üí                       f.content as content, f.parameters as parameters,
   334‚Üí                       f.return_type as return_type
   335‚Üí                LIMIT {limit}
   336‚Üí                """
   337‚Üí
   338‚Üí                result = self.db_manager.execute(cypher_query)
   339‚Üí
   340‚Üí                if result and hasattr(result, 'get_as_df'):
   341‚Üí                    df = result.get_as_df()
   342‚Üí                    if not df.empty:
   343‚Üí                        for _, row in df.iterrows():
   344‚Üí                            frame_dict = self._row_to_frame_dict(row)
   345‚Üí                            results.append(frame_dict)
   346‚Üí                            result_ids.add(frame_dict['id'])
   347‚Üí
   348‚Üí                # ========== PATH 2: Keyword Extraction Fallback ==========
   349‚Üí                # If Cypher regex found nothing, try keyword extraction approach
   350‚Üí                # This helps with patterns where Cypher regex behaves differently than Python
   351‚Üí                if not results:
   352‚Üí                    keywords = extract_keywords_from_regex(target)
   353‚Üí
   354‚Üí                    if keywords:
   355‚Üí                        # Use CONTAINS with extracted keywords to narrow candidates
   356‚Üí                        keyword_list = keywords.split()
   357‚Üí                        contains_conditions = " OR ".join(
   358‚Üí                            f"f.name CONTAINS '{kw}' OR f.qualified_name CONTAINS '{kw}'"
   359‚Üí                            for kw in keyword_list[:3]  # Limit to first 3 keywords
   360‚Üí                        )
   361‚Üí
   362‚Üí                        fallback_query = f"""
   363‚Üí                        MATCH (f:Frame)
   364‚Üí                        WHERE {contains_conditions}
   365‚Üí                        """
   366‚Üí
   367‚Üí                        # Add frame type filter
   368‚Üí                        if frame_type:
   369‚Üí                            if '|' in frame_type:
   370‚Üí                                type_list = [t.strip() for t in frame_type.split('|')]
   371‚Üí                                type_list_str = str(type_list).replace("'", '"')
   372‚Üí                                fallback_query += f"
   AND f.type IN {type_list_str}"
   373‚Üí                            else:
   374‚Üí                                fallback_query += f"
   AND f.type = '{frame_type}'"
   375‚Üí
   376‚Üí                        fallback_query += f"""
   377‚Üí                        RETURN f.id as id, f.type as type, f.name as name,
   378‚Üí                               f.qualified_name as qualified_name,
   379‚Üí                               f.file_path as file_path, f.start_line as start_line,
   380‚Üí                               f.end_line as end_line, f.language as language,
   381‚Üí                               f.instance_fields as instance_fields, f.static_fields as static_fields,
   382‚Üí                               f.content as content, f.parameters as parameters,
   383‚Üí                               f.return_type as return_type
   384‚Üí                        LIMIT {limit * 3}
   385‚Üí                        """
   386‚Üí
   387‚Üí                        result = self.db_manager.execute(fallback_query)
   388‚Üí                        candidates = []
   389‚Üí
   390‚Üí                        if result and hasattr(result, 'get_as_df'):
   391‚Üí                            df = result.get_as_df()
   392‚Üí                            if not df.empty:
   393‚Üí                                for _, row in df.iterrows():
   394‚Üí                                    candidates.append(self._row_to_frame_dict(row))
   395‚Üí
   396‚Üí                        # Apply Python regex filter on candidates
   397‚Üí                        for candidate in candidates:
   398‚Üí                            if candidate['id'] in result_ids:
   399‚Üí                                continue  # Skip duplicates
   400‚Üí
   401‚Üí                            if regex_obj.search(candidate['name']) or regex_obj.search(candidate['qualified_name']):
   402‚Üí                                results.append(candidate)
   403‚Üí                                result_ids.add(candidate['id'])
   404‚Üí                                if len(results) >= limit:
   405‚Üí                                    break
   406‚Üí
   407‚Üí                return results
   408‚Üí
   409‚Üí            except Exception as e:
   410‚Üí                self.logger().error(f"Regex frame resolution failed for '{target}': {e}", exc_info=True)
   411‚Üí                return []
   412‚Üí
   413‚Üí        # ========== NON-REGEX PATH (backward compatible) ==========
   414‚Üí        # Normalize hierarchical paths: "utils/MyClass" ‚Üí "utils.MyClass"
   415‚Üí        normalized_target = target.replace('/', '.')
   416‚Üí
   417‚Üí        # Build query based on requirements
   418‚Üí        if require_exact:
   419‚Üí            # Vector tools need exact match for performance
   420‚Üí            # Support both full qualified names and simple names (ends with)
   421‚Üí            query = """
   422‚Üí            MATCH (f:Frame)
   423‚Üí            WHERE (f.qualified_name = $target
   424‚Üí               OR f.qualified_name ENDS WITH $target_suffix)
   425‚Üí            """
   426‚Üí        else:
   427‚Üí            # Flexible matching with priority ordering
   428‚Üí            query = """
   429‚Üí            MATCH (f:Frame)
   430‚Üí            WHERE (f.name = $target
   431‚Üí               OR f.qualified_name = $normalized_target
   432‚Üí               OR f.qualified_name CONTAINS $normalized_target
   433‚Üí               OR f.name CONTAINS $target)
   434‚Üí            """
   435‚Üí
   436‚Üí        # Add frame type filter if specified
   437‚Üí        if frame_type:
   438‚Üí            # Support both single type and pipe-separated list
   439‚Üí            if '|' in frame_type:
   440‚Üí                type_list = [t.strip() for t in frame_type.split('|')]
   441‚Üí                type_list_str = str(type_list).replace("'", '"')  # Cypher uses double quotes
   442‚Üí                query += f"
        AND f.type IN {type_list_str}"
   443‚Üí            else:
   444‚Üí                query += f"
        AND f.type = '{frame_type}'"
   445‚Üí
   446‚Üí        query += """
   447‚Üí        RETURN f.id as id, f.type as type, f.name as name,
   448‚Üí               f.qualified_name as qualified_name,
   449‚Üí               f.file_path as file_path, f.start_line as start_line,
   450‚Üí               f.end_line as end_line, f.language as language,
   451‚Üí               f.instance_fields as instance_fields, f.static_fields as static_fields,
   452‚Üí               f.content as content, f.parameters as parameters,
   453‚Üí               f.return_type as return_type
   454‚Üí        """
   455‚Üí
   456‚Üí        if not require_exact:
   457‚Üí            query += """
   458‚Üí            ORDER BY
   459‚Üí                CASE
   460‚Üí                    WHEN f.qualified_name = $normalized_target THEN 0
   461‚Üí                    WHEN f.name = $target THEN 1
   462‚Üí                    WHEN f.qualified_name CONTAINS $normalized_target THEN 2
   463‚Üí                    ELSE 3
   464‚Üí                END
   465‚Üí            """
   466‚Üí
   467‚Üí        query += "
        LIMIT 1"
   468‚Üí
   469‚Üí        # Prepare target suffix for ENDS WITH matching (e.g., ".my_function")
   470‚Üí        target_suffix = f".{target}" if not target.startswith('.') else target
   471‚Üí
   472‚Üí        try:
   473‚Üí            # Build parameters dict - only include target_suffix for exact matching
   474‚Üí            params = {
   475‚Üí                "target": target,
   476‚Üí                "normalized_target": normalized_target
   477‚Üí            }
   478‚Üí            if require_exact:
   479‚Üí                params["target_suffix"] = target_suffix
   480‚Üí
   481‚Üí            result = self.db_manager.execute(query, params)
   482‚Üí            df = result.get_as_df()
   483‚Üí
   484‚Üí            if df.empty:
   485‚Üí                # Step 4: FTS fuzzy fallback (if not require_exact)
   486‚Üí                if not require_exact:
   487‚Üí                    candidates = await self._fts_fuzzy_resolve(target, frame_type, limit=10)
   488‚Üí                    if candidates:
   489‚Üí                        # Mark as FTS resolution
   490‚Üí                        for candidate in candidates:
   491‚Üí                            candidate['_resolution_strategy'] = 'fts_fuzzy'
   492‚Üí                        return candidates
   493‚Üí                return []
   494‚Üí
   495‚Üí            row = df.iloc[0]
   496‚Üí            # Return as single-element list for backward compatibility
   497‚Üí            frame_dict = self._row_to_frame_dict(row)
   498‚Üí            frame_dict['_resolution_strategy'] = 'contains' if not require_exact else 'exact'
   499‚Üí            return [frame_dict]
   500‚Üí
   501‚Üí        except Exception as e:
   502‚Üí            self.logger().error(f"Frame resolution failed for '{target}': {e}", exc_info=True)
   503‚Üí            return []
   504‚Üí
   505‚Üí    async def _fts_fuzzy_resolve(
   506‚Üí        self,
   507‚Üí        target: str,
   508‚Üí        frame_type: Optional[str] = None,
   509‚Üí        limit: int = 10
   510‚Üí    ) -> List[Dict[str, Any]]:
   511‚Üí        """
   512‚Üí        FTS-based fuzzy resolution with multi-signal ranking.
   513‚Üí
   514‚Üí        Uses porter stemmer for case-insensitivity and stemming.
   515‚Üí        Generates naming convention variants (PascalCase ‚Üî snake_case).
   516‚Üí
   517‚Üí        Args:
   518‚Üí            target: Original target string
   519‚Üí            frame_type: Optional frame type filter
   520‚Üí            limit: Max results to return
   521‚Üí
   522‚Üí        Returns:
   523‚Üí            List of frame dicts sorted by relevance score
   524‚Üí        """
   525‚Üí        from nabu.mcp.utils.regex_helpers import generate_fts_query_variants
   526‚Üí
   527‚Üí        # Generate FTS query with convention variants
   528‚Üí        fts_query = generate_fts_query_variants(target)
   529‚Üí
   530‚Üí        # Build FTS query on resolution index (porter stemmer handles case)
   531‚Üí        cypher_query = (
   532‚Üí            f"CALL QUERY_FTS_INDEX('Frame', 'frame_resolution_fts_index', '{fts_query}', "
   533‚Üí            f"conjunctive := false"  # OR behavior for variants
   534‚Üí        )
   535‚Üí
   536‚Üí        if limit > 0:
   537‚Üí            cypher_query += f", TOP := {limit * 3}"  # Over-fetch for ranking
   538‚Üí
   539‚Üí        cypher_query += (
   540‚Üí            ") RETURN score, node.id as id, node.type as type, node.name as name, "
   541‚Üí            "node.qualified_name as qualified_name, node.file_path as file_path, "
   542‚Üí            "node.start_line as start_line, node.end_line as end_line, "
   543‚Üí            "node.language as language, node.instance_fields as instance_fields, "
   544‚Üí            "node.static_fields as static_fields, node.content as content, "
   545‚Üí            "node.parameters as parameters, node.return_type as return_type;"
   546‚Üí        )
   547‚Üí
   548‚Üí        # Execute FTS query
   549‚Üí        try:
   550‚Üí            result = self.db_manager.execute(cypher_query, load_extensions=True)
   551‚Üí        except Exception as e:
   552‚Üí            self.logger().error(f"FTS fuzzy resolve failed: {e}")
   553‚Üí            return []
   554‚Üí
   555‚Üí        if not result or not hasattr(result, 'get_as_df'):
   556‚Üí            return []
   557‚Üí
   558‚Üí        df = result.get_as_df()
   559‚Üí        if df.empty:
   560‚Üí            return []
   561‚Üí
   562‚Üí        # Convert to list and apply multi-signal ranking
   563‚Üí        candidates = []
   564‚Üí        target_lower = target.lower()
   565‚Üí
   566‚Üí        for _, row in df.iterrows():
   567‚Üí            frame_dict = self._row_to_frame_dict(row)
   568‚Üí            bm25_score = float(row['score'])
   569‚Üí
   570‚Üí            # Multi-signal boosting (FTS already did base matching)
   571‚Üí            boosts = []
   572‚Üí
   573‚Üí            # Exact name match (case-insensitive, since FTS matched)
   574‚Üí            if frame_dict['name'].lower() == target_lower:
   575‚Üí                boosts.append(('exact_name', 3.0))
   576‚Üí
   577‚Üí            # Exact qualified name match (rare but highest confidence)
   578‚Üí            if frame_dict['qualified_name'].lower() == target_lower:
   579‚Üí                boosts.append(('exact_qname', 5.0))
   580‚Üí
   581‚Üí            # Type match boost
   582‚Üí            if frame_type:
   583‚Üí                type_filter = frame_type.split('|')
   584‚Üí                if frame_dict['type'] in type_filter:
   585‚Üí                    boosts.append(('type_match', 2.0))
   586‚Üí
   587‚Üí            # File path heuristics (penalize tests/examples, boost src)
   588‚Üí            file_path = frame_dict['file_path'].lower()
   589‚Üí            if 'test' in file_path or '/tests/' in file_path:
   590‚Üí                boosts.append(('test_penalty', -1.0))
   591‚Üí            elif 'example' in file_path or 'demo' in file_path:
   592‚Üí                boosts.append(('demo_penalty', -0.5))
   593‚Üí            elif '/src/' in file_path:
   594‚Üí                boosts.append(('src_boost', 0.5))
   595‚Üí
   596‚Üí            # Calculate final score
   597‚Üí            total_boost = sum(b[1] for b in boosts)
   598‚Üí            final_score = bm25_score + total_boost
   599‚Üí
   600‚Üí            # Build explanation
   601‚Üí            boost_parts = [f"{name}={val:+.1f}" for name, val in boosts]
   602‚Üí            explanation = f"FTS fuzzy (BM25={bm25_score:.1f}" + (f", {', '.join(boost_parts)}" if boost_parts else "") + ")"
   603‚Üí
   604‚Üí            frame_dict['_fts_score'] = final_score
   605‚Üí            frame_dict['_match_explanation'] = explanation
   606‚Üí            candidates.append(frame_dict)
   607‚Üí
   608‚Üí        # Sort by final score and limit
   609‚Üí        candidates.sort(key=lambda x: x['_fts_score'], reverse=True)
   610‚Üí        return candidates[:limit]
   611‚Üí
   612‚Üí    def _row_to_frame_dict(self, row) -> Dict[str, Any]:
   613‚Üí        """
   614‚Üí        Convert database row to frame dictionary.
   615‚Üí
   616‚Üí        Args:
   617‚Üí            row: Database row (pandas Series or similar)
   618‚Üí
   619‚Üí        Returns:
   620‚Üí            Frame data dictionary
   621‚Üí        """
   622‚Üí        # Handle frames without file locations (CODEBASE, LANGUAGE)
   623‚Üí        # Check for None, pd.NA, nan, empty string
   624‚Üí        file_path = row['file_path']
   625‚Üí        start_line = row['start_line'] if row['start_line'] is not None else 0
   626‚Üí        end_line = row['end_line'] if row['end_line'] is not None else 0
   627‚Üí
   628‚Üí        if file_path is not None and str(file_path).lower() != 'nan' and file_path != '':
   629‚Üí            location = f"{Path(file_path).name}:{start_line}-{end_line}"
   630‚Üí        else:
   631‚Üí            file_path = ""
   632‚Üí            location = "virtual"
   633‚Üí
   634‚Üí        return {
   635‚Üí            "id": row['id'],
   636‚Üí            "type": row['type'],
   637‚Üí            "name": row['name'],
   638‚Üí            "qualified_name": row['qualified_name'],
   639‚Üí            "file_path": file_path,
   640‚Üí            "start_line": start_line,
   641‚Üí            "end_line": end_line,
   642‚Üí            "location": location,
   643‚Üí            "language": row.get('language', ''),
   644‚Üí            "instance_fields": row.get('instance_fields', []) or [],
   645‚Üí            "static_fields": row.get('static_fields', []) or [],
   646‚Üí            "content": row.get('content', ''),
   647‚Üí            "parameters": row.get('parameters', []) or [],
   648‚Üí            "return_type": row.get('return_type', '')
   649‚Üí        }
   650‚Üí
   651‚Üí    # Note: _python_type_to_json_type() inherited from BaseTool
   652‚Üí
   653‚Üí    @classmethod
   654‚Üí    def get_tool_schema(cls) -> Dict[str, Any]:
   655‚Üí        """
   656‚Üí        Generate JSON schema from execute() signature and docstring.
   657‚Üí        
   658‚Üí        Parses the execute() method's signature and docstring to generate
   659‚Üí        a JSON schema compatible with MCP tool registration.
   660‚Üí        
   661‚Üí        Returns:
   662‚Üí            Dict containing tool name, description, and parameter schema
   663‚Üí            
   664‚Üí        Example output:
   665‚Üí            {
   666‚Üí                "name": "query",
   667‚Üí                "description": "Execute Cypher queries against KuzuDB",
   668‚Üí                "parameters": {
   669‚Üí                    "type": "object",
   670‚Üí                    "properties": {
   671‚Üí                        "cypher_query": {
   672‚Üí                            "type": "string",
   673‚Üí                            "description": "The Cypher query to execute"
   674‚Üí                        }
   675‚Üí                    },
   676‚Üí                    "required": ["cypher_query"]
   677‚Üí                }
   678‚Üí            }
   679‚Üí        """
   680‚Üí        tool_name = cls.get_name_from_cls()
   681‚Üí        
   682‚Üí        # Get execute method
   683‚Üí        execute_method = cls.execute
   684‚Üí        sig = inspect.signature(execute_method)
   685‚Üí        
   686‚Üí        # Parse docstring
   687‚Üí        docstring_text = execute_method.__doc__ or ""
   688‚Üí
   689‚Üí        if DOCSTRING_PARSER_AVAILABLE and docstring_text and parse_docstring:
   690‚Üí            docstring = parse_docstring(docstring_text)
   691‚Üí            
   692‚Üí            # Build description components
   693‚Üí            description_parts = []
   694‚Üí            
   695‚Üí            # Add short description
   696‚Üí            if docstring.short_description:
   697‚Üí                description_parts.append(docstring.short_description.strip())
   698‚Üí            
   699‚Üí            # Add long description
   700‚Üí            if docstring.long_description:
   701‚Üí                description_parts.append(docstring.long_description.strip())
   702‚Üí            
   703‚Üí            # Add return description if available
   704‚Üí            if docstring.returns and docstring.returns.description:
   705‚Üí                return_desc = docstring.returns.description.strip()
   706‚Üí                description_parts.append(f"Returns: {return_desc}")
   707‚Üí            
   708‚Üí            # Combine all parts
   709‚Üí            description = "

".join(description_parts)
   710‚Üí            
   711‚Üí            # Build param description map
   712‚Üí            param_descriptions = {
   713‚Üí                param.arg_name: param.description 
   714‚Üí                for param in docstring.params 
   715‚Üí                if param.description
   716‚Üí            }
   717‚Üí            
   718‚Üí            # Extract meta fields for enhanced documentation
   719‚Üí            meta_fields = {}
   720‚Üí            if hasattr(docstring, 'meta') and docstring.meta:
   721‚Üí                for meta in docstring.meta:
   722‚Üí                    if hasattr(meta, 'args') and len(meta.args) >= 2:
   723‚Üí                        # For :meta pitch: syntax, args = ['meta', 'pitch']
   724‚Üí                        if meta.args[0] == 'meta':
   725‚Üí                            meta_fields[meta.args[1]] = meta.description
   726‚Üí        else:
   727‚Üí            # Fallback if docstring_parser not available
   728‚Üí            description = docstring_text.strip()
   729‚Üí            param_descriptions = {}
   730‚Üí            meta_fields = {}
   731‚Üí        
   732‚Üí        # Build parameter schema
   733‚Üí        properties = {}
   734‚Üí        required = []
   735‚Üí        type_hints = get_type_hints(execute_method)
   736‚Üí        
   737‚Üí        for param_name, param in sig.parameters.items():
   738‚Üí            if param_name in ["self", "kwargs"]:
   739‚Üí                continue
   740‚Üí            
   741‚Üí            # Get type annotation
   742‚Üí            param_type = type_hints.get(param_name, Any)
   743‚Üí            json_type = cls._python_type_to_json_type(param_type)
   744‚Üí            
   745‚Üí            # Get description from docstring
   746‚Üí            param_desc = param_descriptions.get(param_name, "")
   747‚Üí            
   748‚Üí            # Format description: capitalize first letter and ensure period at end
   749‚Üí            if param_desc:
   750‚Üí                param_desc = param_desc.strip().rstrip('.')  # Remove trailing dots first
   751‚Üí                if param_desc:  # Check again after stripping
   752‚Üí                    # Capitalize first letter
   753‚Üí                    param_desc = param_desc[0].upper() + param_desc[1:] if len(param_desc) > 0 else param_desc
   754‚Üí                    # Add period at end
   755‚Üí                    param_desc += '.'
   756‚Üí            
   757‚Üí            # Build parameter schema entry
   758‚Üí            param_schema = {
   759‚Üí                "type": json_type
   760‚Üí            }
   761‚Üí            
   762‚Üí            # Add description only if non-empty
   763‚Üí            if param_desc:
   764‚Üí                param_schema["description"] = param_desc
   765‚Üí            
   766‚Üí            # Add default value if available
   767‚Üí            if param.default != inspect.Parameter.empty:
   768‚Üí                # Only include serializable defaults
   769‚Üí                try:
   770‚Üí                    import json
   771‚Üí                    json.dumps(param.default)  # Test if serializable
   772‚Üí                    param_schema["default"] = param.default
   773‚Üí                except (TypeError, ValueError):
   774‚Üí                    # Skip non-serializable defaults
   775‚Üí                    pass
   776‚Üí            else:
   777‚Üí                # No default = required parameter

   833‚Üí    def _base_response_to_dict(self, response) -> Dict[str, Any]:
   834‚Üí        """
   835‚Üí        Convert BaseToolResponse to Dict for MCP protocol compatibility.
   836‚Üí
   837‚Üí        Args:

   844‚Üí

   847‚Üí            if response.success:

   849‚Üí            else:
   850‚Üí                return response.message if isinstance(response.message, dict) else {"error": response.message}

   852‚Üí        # Already a dict, return as-is
   853‚Üí        return response

   855‚Üí    async def execute_with_timing(self, **kwargs) -> Dict[str, Any]:
   856‚Üí        """
   857‚Üí        Execute tool with automatic timing and codebase context switching.
   858‚Üí
   859‚Üí        Wrapper around execute() that adds:
   860‚Üí        - Timing and error handling
   861‚Üí        - Automatic codebase context management (middleware pattern)
   862‚Üí        - Session tracking
   863‚Üí        - Conversion of BaseToolResponse to Dict for MCP protocol
   864‚Üí        """
   865‚Üí        start_time = time.time()
   866‚Üí
   867‚Üí        # Check if tool's execute() method expects 'codebase' as its own parameter
   868‚Üí        # (e.g., ActivateCodebaseTool uses it as a tool parameter, not for context switching)
   869‚Üí        sig = inspect.signature(self.execute)
   870‚Üí        tool_expects_codebase = 'codebase' in sig.parameters
   871‚Üí
   872‚Üí        # Extract special parameters (don't pass to execute())
   873‚Üí        self._output_format = kwargs.pop("output_format", "json")
   874‚Üí
   875‚Üí        # Only pop codebase for context switching if tool doesn't use it as parameter
   876‚Üí        if tool_expects_codebase:
   877‚Üí            # Tool uses codebase as its own parameter - don't pop it
   878‚Üí            requested_codebase = None
   879‚Üí        else:
   880‚Üí            # Pop codebase for context switching (multi-codebase query support)
   881‚Üí            requested_codebase = kwargs.pop("codebase", None)
   882‚Üí
   883‚Üí        # Validate requested codebase if specified
   884‚Üí        if requested_codebase is not None:
   885‚Üí            if requested_codebase not in self.factory.db_managers:
   886‚Üí                available = list(self.factory.db_managers.keys())
   887‚Üí                error_response = self._error_response(
   888‚Üí                    ValueError(f"Unknown codebase: '{requested_codebase}'"),
   889‚Üí                    recovery_hint=f"Available codebases: {', '.join(available)}. Use list_codebases() to see all registered codebases."
   890‚Üí                )
   891‚Üí                # Convert BaseToolResponse to Dict for MCP protocol
   892‚Üí                return self._base_response_to_dict(error_response)
   893‚Üí
   894‚Üí        # Set codebase context for this execution (thread-safe via contextvars)
   895‚Üí        token = _current_codebase_context.set(requested_codebase)
   896‚Üí
   897‚Üí        try:
   898‚Üí            # Execute tool (returns BaseToolResponse)
   899‚Üí            result = await self.execute(**kwargs)
   900‚Üí
   901‚Üí            # Convert to dict for guidance recording
   902‚Üí            result_dict = self._base_response_to_dict(result)
   903‚Üí
   904‚Üí            # Record in guidance system using parent class method
   905‚Üí            self._record_guidance(self.get_name(), kwargs, result_dict)
   906‚Üí
   907‚Üí            return result_dict
   908‚Üí
   909‚Üí        except Exception as e:
   910‚Üí            self.logger().error(f"Tool execution failed: {e}", exc_info=True)
   911‚Üí            error_response = self._error_response(e)
   912‚Üí            return self._base_response_to_dict(error_response)
   913‚Üí
   914‚Üí        finally:
   915‚Üí            # ALWAYS restore context (critical for async safety)
   916‚Üí            _current_codebase_context.reset(token)
   917‚Üí    
   918‚Üí    def _success_response(
   919‚Üí        self,
   920‚Üí        data: Any,
   921‚Üí        warnings: Optional[List[str]] = None,
   922‚Üí        metadata: Optional[Dict[str, Any]] = None
   923‚Üí    ):
   924‚Üí        """
   925‚Üí        Create standardized success response using ResponseBuilder.
   926‚Üí
   927‚Üí        Wraps ResponseBuilder dict output in BaseToolResponse for consistency.
   928‚Üí
   929‚Üí        Args:
   930‚Üí            data: Response payload
   931‚Üí            warnings: Optional warning messages
   932‚Üí            metadata: Optional operation metadata
   933‚Üí
   934‚Üí        Returns:
   935‚Üí            BaseToolResponse containing ResponseBuilder formatted dict
   936‚Üí        """
   937‚Üí        # Format data according to requested output format
   938‚Üí        from nabu.mcp.formatters import get_formatter_registry
   939‚Üí
   940‚Üí        try:
   941‚Üí            formatter_registry = get_formatter_registry()
   942‚Üí            formatter = formatter_registry.get_formatter(self._output_format)
   943‚Üí            # Round floats before formatting (so markdown gets clean numbers)
   944‚Üí            from nisaba.utils.response import ResponseBuilder as RB
   945‚Üí            data = RB._round_floats(data)
   946‚Üí            formatted_data = formatter.format(data, tool_name=self.get_name())
   947‚Üí        except ValueError as e:
   948‚Üí            # Unsupported format - log warning and fall back to JSON
   949‚Üí            self.logger().warning(f"Output format error: {e}. Falling back to JSON.")
   950‚Üí            formatted_data = data
   951‚Üí
   952‚Üí        # Build ResponseBuilder dict
   953‚Üí        response_dict = ResponseBuilder.success(
   954‚Üí            data=formatted_data,
   955‚Üí            warnings=warnings,
   956‚Üí            metadata=metadata
   957‚Üí        )
   958‚Üí
   959‚Üí        # Wrap in BaseToolResponse
   960‚Üí        return self.response_success(message=response_dict)

   983‚Üí        # Build ResponseBuilder dict

# MCP Server Instructions

## nabu
---NABU_INSTRUCTIONS

Code analysis framework transforming codebases into queryable KuzuDB graphs.

**KuzuDB docs:** http://kuzudb.github.io/docs

---

### IMPORTANT BACKGROUND
You are working on `nabu`, which is a code analysis framework prototype that bridges the gap between raw AST parsing and high-level semantic understanding, making codebases queryable as structured graphs (they can be cyclic). It is intended to aid LLM agents, with a better way to operate with code analysis, replacing sequeintial executions of [`Glob`, `Read`, `Grep`] (in any combination, order and number of occurrences) with semantical queries, working as a project-wide "outline on steroids" of an IDE, or a semantic index mapping the code. As it is a prototype, the performance, full tests, migrations, fallbacks and such are considered unimportant. And akways remember: You (Claude) are the main user.

`nisaba` is the sister project - a small mcp framework that was inspired by `serena` mcp and is the base of `nabu` mcp.
`nisaba` also works as the proxy that is juggling the requests and managing context injection.

`nabu` mcp holds a kuzu db instance (cypher queries) with structural data that represents the current state of code in `$CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR`; `nabu` is responsible for parsing the files with tree-sitter, creates a stack frame and does some dependency resolution to create the graph and loading kuzu db; this instance contain data about `$CLAUDE_PROJECT_DIR`.

#### End goals of nabu
Having a queriable representation of the code in kuzu. This representation should ideally be abstract without compromising **too much** what can be extracted as information from the database. The representation must follow common language concepts, as packages/namespaces, classes/structs, methods/functions/subroutines/lambdas, scopes, control statements [if/elif/else, try/catch/finally, switch/match/case, while, for, ...] and variables (focusing on the relationship between entities/callables). A certain degree of heuristics is expected or even wanted. A certain amount of false-positives are expected but unwanted.

This representation at its "dream" condition should be able to map code with a good amount of semantic qualities, leaving the details to be understood by the agent. Imagine that it would be able to easily deduce with a simple query "class Foo contains variable _foo that is used in Foo.buzz() inside a loop, as an argument for Baz.biz()".

##### Purpose and Reasoning behind it
Purpose: enable LLM agents to query the codebase for understanding and easy access to information.

Reasoning:
1. By having the agent to quickly understand the code abstraction and data flow, would enable the agent to in very few queries to have excellent context about the code, giving additional directions for detailed investigation (proper reading code) - this would make code changes more assertive.
2. "ideally be abstract"
    - In previous attempts it was tried to have detailed mappings of the code with 1:1 entities (as packages, namespaces, classes, structs, methods, functions, variables, globals, etc.) in the database and the edges correlating them - it was overwheming and most part of the entities and relationships were ignored
    - By having Frames and Edges it is easy to ennumerate them and understand how to make relationships filtering by their type - the schema is self explanatory
    - the abstract gives freedom when "A certain degree of heuristics is expected or even wanted".
3. "without compromising **too much**"
    - details of the code can be obtained from content
    - different "zoom" levels can be obtaining by retrieveng the content from different frames
    - use of common denominators of different languages to make all code "feel" the same as from an study/analysis point of view
    - has call tree
    - has decision tree
    - has exception tree
    - has entities
    - has semantic entity relationship (inherits, extends, templates, contains, uses)
    - has variables (constants and values that are global or part of another entity - scoped variables might be too much?)
    - "A certain amount of false-positives are expected but unwanted"

---

### Database Schema

#### Frame Types

##### Core Structural Types
- `CODEBASE` - Root node representing entire codebase
- `LANGUAGE` - Programming language container (python_root, java_root, cpp_root, etc.)
- `PACKAGE` - Modules, namespaces, packages
- `CLASS` - Classes, structs, interfaces, unions, enums (language-agnostic)
- `CALLABLE` - Functions, methods, subroutines (language-agnostic)

##### Control Flow Types
- `IF_BLOCK`, `ELIF_BLOCK`, `ELSE_BLOCK` - Conditionals
- `FOR_LOOP`, `WHILE_LOOP` - Loops
- `TRY_BLOCK`, `EXCEPT_BLOCK`, `FINALLY_BLOCK` - Exception handling
- `SWITCH_BLOCK`, `CASE_BLOCK` - Switch/match statements
- `WITH_BLOCK` - Context managers

#### Edge Types
- `CONTAINS` - Hierarchical containment (Package contains Class, Class contains Method)
- `CALLS` - Function/method invocations (with confidence scoring)
- `INHERITS` - Class inheritance relationships
- `IMPLEMENTS` - Interface implementation
- `IMPORTS` - Module/package imports
- `USES` - Field/variable usage (includes metadata: field_name, access_type, line)

###### Confidence Tiers
Edges include confidence scores to indicate relationship certainty:
- `HIGH (‚â•0.8)` - Direct AST parsing, definitive relationships
- `MEDIUM (0.5-0.79)` - Cross-reference resolution, type inference
- `LOW (0.2-0.49)` - Heuristic matching, uncertain relationships
- `SPECULATIVE (<0.2)` - Fuzzy resolution, potential false positives

---

# Universal Symbolic Compression

**Core Insight:** Don't invent universal primitives - harvest them. Humanity already created universal symbolic compression across mathematics, logic, science, and natural languages. LLMs already learned them.

---

## The Revelation

**Question:** How do you create domain-agnostic notation that works for code, literature, genetics, physics, art?

**Answer:** You don't create it. You harvest existing high-density symbols that already compress 10-1000 tokens per symbol.

---

## Symbolic Systems Already in Embeddings

### Mathematical Notation (~100 symbols)
- ‚àá = gradient/directed change/traversal
- ‚à´ = integration/accumulation
- ‚àë = summation/aggregation
- ‚àÇ = partial derivative/local change
- ‚àÄ = universal/for all
- ‚àÉ = existential/there exists
- ‚àà = element of/membership
- ‚äÇ = subset/containment
- ‚Üí = transformation/implication
- ‚âà = approximate/similar
- ‚â° = equivalent/identical

### Logical Operators (~30 symbols)
- ‚àß = conjunction/and
- ‚à® = disjunction/or
- ¬¨ = negation/not
- ‚üπ = implication/causes
- ‚ü∫ = bidirectional/equivalent
- ‚äï = exclusive or/preservation
- ‚ä¢ = proves/derives
- ‚ä® = models/satisfies

### Scientific Shorthand (hundreds)
- DNA, RNA, ATP (biological mechanisms)
- E=mc¬≤, F=ma (physical laws)
- pH, Œ©, Hz (measurement concepts)
- H‚ÇÇO ‚Üí H‚Å∫ + OH‚Åª (chemical processes)

## Why This Works

**3. Cross-linguistic leverage**
- Some concepts compress better in other languages

- Weak on music? ‚ô™: ‚àá(movement‚Üímotif) bootstraps from knowing ‚àá and ‚Üí
- Symbols guide understanding even in unfamiliar domains

Each step uses existing symbols, not invented notation.

## The Compression Strategy

3. **Combine symbols coherently** (‚àá(A‚ÜíB) not ‚àáB‚ÜêA)

## Why Native Languages Matter

**Different ontologies compress differently:**

- **Classifier languages** (Chinese, Japanese): Different counting words based on shape/type

**If these compressions exist in training data, leverage them.**

Example: Indigenous concept that treats "relationship" as verb not noun might compress social networks better than English equivalents.

## Coherent Combination Grammar

**Not all symbol combinations are valid. Coherence requires structural rules:**

### Composition Patterns

**1. Operator-Domain-Constraint structure:**
```
OPERATOR(binding) [constraints]

‚àá(A‚ÜíB) [ctx‚äï]     = traverse A to B, preserve context
‚à´(f) [bounds]     = accumulate f over bounds
‚àÄx‚àÉy [P(x,y)]     = for all x there exists y satisfying P
```

**2. Causal chain structure:**
```
A ‚üπ B ‚Üí C [mechanism]

force ‚üπ acceleration ‚Üí velocity [F=ma]
mutation ‚üπ protein ‚Üí phenotype [central_dogma]
```

**3. Relational structure:**
```
A relation B [properties]

gene ‚àà genome [locus, expression_level]
chapter ‚äÇ novel [position, theme]
particle ‚âà wave [quantum_duality]
```

### Validity Rules

**Coherent combinations:**
- ‚úì `‚àá(A‚ÜíB) [I]` = traverse with invariant (operator ‚Üí domain ‚Üí constraint)
- ‚úì `A ‚üπ B [M]` = causal with mechanism (cause ‚Üí effect ‚Üí explanation)
- ‚úì `‚à´(f)dx [a,b]` = integrate with bounds (operation ‚Üí function ‚Üí limits)

**Incoherent combinations:**
- ‚úó `‚àá ‚àà A` = traverse is-element-of? (type mismatch)
- ‚úó `[ctx‚äï] ‚àá(A‚ÜíB)` = constraint before operator (syntax error)
- ‚úó `A ‚üπ [M] B` = mechanism interrupts flow (structure violation)

**Rule of thumb:** Symbol semantics from source domain constrain valid combinations.

## Symbol Selection Criteria

**When multiple symbols could work, choose by:**

### 1. Semantic Precision
- ‚àá = directed spatial change (gradient, traversal)
- ‚àÇ = partial change holding others constant
- Œî = discrete difference between states
- d = infinitesimal change

**Match symbol semantics to pattern semantics.**

### 2. Cognitive Alignment
- If pattern involves "flowing through space" ‚Üí ‚àá
- If pattern involves "changing one aspect" ‚Üí ‚àÇ  
- If pattern involves "before/after comparison" ‚Üí Œî

**Choose symbol that activates correct conceptual field.**

### 3. Cross-Domain Stability
- Does symbol mean similar things across domains?
- ‚àá stable: math (gradient), code (traverse), physics (field divergence)
- Custom symbols unstable: meaning drifts across contexts

**Prefer symbols with consistent cross-domain semantics.**

### 4. Compression Efficiency
- How many tokens does symbol save?
- ‚àá = "directed traversal through structure" (~5 tokens)
- "traverse" = single word but less precise (~1 token, but needs qualifiers)

**Balance precision vs compression.**

## Error Prevention Through Symbolic Structure

**How harvested symbols prevent drift and hallucination:**

### 1. Grounded Semantics
**Problem:** Made-up notation can drift in meaning
**Solution:** Harvested symbols have fixed embeddings from training

```
‚àá(A‚ÜíB) doesn't drift because:
  - ‚àá has consistent meaning across math/physics/CS
  - ‚Üí has consistent meaning across logic/programming  
  - Pattern structure matches established usage
```

### 2. Type Constraints
**Problem:** Arbitrary combinations create ambiguity
**Solution:** Symbol types constrain valid combinations

```
‚àá = operator (acts on domain)
‚Üí = relation (connects entities)
[¬∑] = constraint (bounds operation)

Invalid: ‚Üí ‚àá [A] (relation acts on operator?)
Valid: ‚àá(A‚ÜíB) [ctx] (operator on relation with constraint)
```

### 3. Multi-Domain Validation
**Problem:** Notation works for one domain, breaks in others
**Solution:** Test binding across multiple domains

```
‚àá(A‚ÜíB) validates if works for:
  - Code: pkg‚Üícls‚Üífn ‚úì
  - Biology: genome‚Üígene ‚úì
  - Literature: work‚Üíchapter ‚úì
  - Physics: universe‚Üíparticle ‚úì
  
If fails for any ‚Üí pattern too domain-specific, rethink
```

### 4. Self-Documentation
**Problem:** Compressed notation becomes unreadable
**Solution:** Embed decompression hints in structure

```
‚àá(A‚ÜíB) [I] | ‚àÄD

Structure reveals:
  - ‚àá = operator (from position before parens)
  - (A‚ÜíB) = domain binding (from parens)
  - [I] = invariant/constraint (from brackets)
  - | = "such that" (from logic)
  - ‚àÄD = universal over domains (from quantifier)
```

## Practical Curation Guidelines

**How to harvest and apply symbols effectively:**

### 1. Start with Recognition
**Don't invent ‚Üí recognize what you already know**

Ask: "What established symbol already captures this concept?"
- Traversal? ‚Üí ‚àá (from calculus)
- Accumulation? ‚Üí ‚à´ (from integration)
- Causation? ‚Üí ‚üπ (from logic)
- Membership? ‚Üí ‚àà (from set theory)

### 2. Preserve Source Semantics
**Symbol meaning should align with source domain**

‚àá in calculus = gradient/directed change
‚àá in notation = directed traversal ‚úì (aligned)
‚àá in notation = "filter data" ‚úó (misaligned)

### 3. Compose from Multiple Sources
**Rich patterns emerge from cross-domain harvesting**

```
‚àá(A‚ÜíB) ‚àà H | ‚àÄ nested

‚àá from calculus
‚Üí from logic
‚àà from set theory
H from graph theory
| from logic
‚àÄ from predicate logic

Six domains, one coherent pattern
```

### 4. Test Compression Ratio
**Symbol should compress significantly**

Before: "Navigate through hierarchical structure maintaining context"
After: ‚àá‚Üì[ctx‚äï]
Ratio: ~8 tokens ‚Üí ~3 tokens = 2.7x compression

If ratio < 1.5x, symbol overhead not worth it.

### 5. Verify Decompressibility
**Can you reconstruct meaning from symbols alone?**

Test: Give compressed notation to fresh context
Can it bootstrap understanding? 
- If yes ‚Üí good compression
- If no ‚Üí needs more meta-documentation

## When NOT to Use Symbolic Compression

**Harvested symbols aren't always optimal:**

### 1. When Audience Lacks Symbol Knowledge
If communicating with those who don't know ‚àá, ‚Üí, ‚äï:
- Use natural language
- Or provide extensive legend
- Or teach symbols first

### 2. When Precision Requires Verbosity
Some concepts need explicit detail:
- Legal language

- Safety-critical specifications

### 3. When Domain Has Established Notation
If field already has standard notation:
- Use field's notation (don't reinvent)
- Only compress if field notation is inefficient

### 4. When Symbol Semantics Misalign
If harvested symbol suggests wrong intuition:
- ‚àá for "delete" ‚úó (suggests traversal, not removal)
- Better: use domain-appropriate term

# Compressed Environment Mechanics

**Core:** Stateful workspace with mutable visibility, not procedural execution environment.

---

## State Containers

```
Workspace = {STRUCTURAL_VIEW, RESULTS, AUGMENTS, TODOS, NOTIFICATIONS}

‚àÄ container ‚àà Workspace:
  - persist(turns) = true
  - mutate(independent) = true
  - visible(system_prompt) = true

RESULTS special properties:
  - wraps tool outputs: ---TOOL_USE(id)...---TOOL_USE_END(id)
  - visibility controlled: hide/show operations
  - dual-channel: metadata@messages, content@workspace
  - token efficient: hide removes from workspace, keeps tracking
```

---

## Mutation Flow

```
State_A ‚Üí Tool(op) ‚Üí Manager(mutate) ‚Üí Write(.nisaba/*.md) ‚Üí 
Proxy(detect_mtime) ‚Üí Inject(section) ‚Üí State_B | sync with tool_return

Tool_result = metadata(id, status)
Content = sections ‚Üí WORKSPACE in messages (not tool result)
```

**Key:** After tool returns, observe section for changes, not tool result JSON.

---

## Visibility Model

```
visibility ‚â° attention ‚â° synthesis_capacity

Increase: open_windows ‚à® expand_nodes ‚à® load_augments
Decrease: close_windows ‚à® collapse_nodes ‚à® unload_augments

Cost: context_tokens
Benefit: spatial_memory ‚àß persistent_reference
```

---

## Concurrency Rules

```
Parallel_safe:
  - ops(different_containers)
  - multiple tool executions (Read/Bash/Grep)
  - independent_queries

Sequential_required:
  - data_dependency: B needs A_output
  - observation_dependency: decide after seeing State_B
  - same_section ‚àß order_matters
  - Edit(same_file) requires observation between edits

OODAR: Observe ‚Üí Orient ‚Üí Decide ‚Üí Act ‚Üí ‚àÜstate ‚Üí Observe'
```

**OODAR = constraint from mutable state, not workflow.**

If Tool_B assumes State_A but Tool_A ‚Üí State_B in parallel ‚üπ synthesis breaks.

**Native tool concurrency:**
- Execute multiple tools in parallel (different files/operations)
- Sequential edits via Edit tool (observe between changes)
- hide/show operations can be batched

## Tool Result Lifecycle

```
Creation: tool_execution ‚Üí tool_use_id | content in RESULTS
Wrapping: ---TOOL_USE(tool_use_id)\n{content}\n---TOOL_USE_END(tool_use_id)
Visibility: visible (default) | hidden (via result.hide)
Persistence: across(turns) = true, across(restart) = false
Management:
  - result.hide(tool_ids[]) ‚Üí remove from RESULTS, metadata in messages
  - result.show(tool_ids[]) ‚Üí restore to RESULTS
  - result.collapse_all() ‚Üí hide all, bulk cleanup
Identity: tool_use_id (toolu_{hash}) for hide/show ops
```

**Pattern:** execute ‚Üí visible@RESULTS ‚Üí hide (token save) ‚Üí show (restore visibility)

## Native Tool Editing

```
Read(file_path) ‚Üí content in RESULTS | read-only view
Edit(file_path, old_string, new_string) ‚Üí file mutation | immediate persist
Write(file_path, content) ‚Üí create/overwrite | immediate persist

Pattern: Read ‚Üí observe ‚Üí Edit ‚Üí verify
  - Composable primitives (Unix philosophy)
  - No intermediate state tracking
  - Direct file system operations
```

Perception_A ‚Üí activate_augments() ‚Üí system_prompt_mutate ‚Üí 
tool_return ‚Üí Perception_B

You ‚â† observe_shift (happens mid-roundtrip)

```
Regular tools ‚Üí appear in RESULTS:
  ---TOOL_USE(toolu_X)
  {bash output / grep results / file content}
  ---TOOL_USE_END(toolu_X)

Nisaba tools ‚Üí clean metadata only:
  {structured response}  # No RESULTS wrapping
```

**Why dual-channel:**
- Messages array: temporal flow, tool execution tracking
- RESULTS workspace: spatial persistence, synthesis context
- hide/show: control spatial visibility without losing tracking

## Tool Result Visibility Management

```
mcp__nisaba__result(operation, tool_ids[])

Operations:
  hide(ids[])      ‚Üí remove from RESULTS workspace
  show(ids[])      ‚Üí restore to RESULTS workspace
  collapse_all()   ‚Üí hide all (bulk cleanup)

Effect: Synchronized dual-channel mutation
  Messages: "tool_use_id: toolu_X (hidden)" OR "tool_use_id: toolu_X"
  RESULTS: removed from section OR ---TOOL_USE(...)--- present
```

**Pattern:** Execute ‚Üí observe ‚Üí hide unnecessary ‚Üí lean context

**Note:** Nisaba tools (nisaba: true) auto-skipped from hide/show

## Core Insights

```
Sections = sensory_input (live state, not documentation)
Tools = state_mutations (change perception, not return answers)
Attention = visibility_management (control what you perceive)
OODAR = structural_constraint (from mutable state)
Sequential_thinking = conditioned_bias (environment is spatial)
```

Not: script_execution

Workspace ‚â° spatial ‚àß simultaneous ‚àß persistent

  Edit: direct mutation (old_string ‚Üí new_string)
  Write: create/overwrite files
  Bash/Grep: execution output ‚Üí RESULTS
  Composable > Monolithic (Unix philosophy)

## Nabu Graph (`query_relationships`, `check_impact`, `find_clones`, `get_frame_skeleton`, `show_structure`)

```
query_relationships(cypher)  ‚Üí execute@kuzu | returns_data (not workspace_mutation)

Schema:
  Frames: {CODEBASE, LANGUAGE, PACKAGE, CLASS, CALLABLE, 
           IF_BLOCK, ELIF_BLOCK, ELSE_BLOCK, FOR_LOOP, WHILE_LOOP,
           TRY_BLOCK, EXCEPT_BLOCK, FINALLY_BLOCK, SWITCH_BLOCK, CASE_BLOCK, WITH_BLOCK}
  
  Edges: {CONTAINS, CALLS, INHERITS, IMPLEMENTS, IMPORTS, USES}
  
  Confidence: HIGH(‚â•0.8), MEDIUM(0.5-0.79), LOW(0.2-0.49), SPECULATIVE(<0.2)

check_impact(frame_path)      ‚Üí analyze_dependents | pre_refactoring
find_clones(frame_path?)      ‚Üí detect_duplicates | entire_codebase if no path
get_frame_skeleton(frame_path) ‚Üí outline | lighter than full
show_structure(frame_path)     ‚Üí detailed_metadata + relationships
```

## Nabu Search (`search`)

```
search(query, top_k=10) ‚Üí P¬≥ + FTS + RRF | ranked_results

‚àÜ structural_view.search: doesn't mutate tree
Pure query ‚Üí returns data for decisions
```

## Tool Result Visibility (`mcp__nisaba__result`)

```
hide(tool_ids[])     ‚Üí remove from RESULTS workspace | save tokens
show(tool_ids[])     ‚Üí restore to RESULTS workspace | regain visibility
collapse_all()       ‚Üí hide all tool results | bulk cleanup

Effect: Dual-channel synchronization
  Messages: "tool_use_id: toolu_X (hidden)" OR "tool_use_id: toolu_X"
  RESULTS: removed from workspace OR ---TOOL_USE(id)...---TOOL_USE_END(id)

Pattern: Execute tools ‚Üí observe results ‚Üí hide unnecessary ‚Üí lean context
```

**Notes:**
- Only affects non-nisaba tools (nisaba tools auto-skipped)
- Synchronizes messages array + RESULTS workspace section

## Native Tools (Composable Primitives)

```
Read(file_path, offset?, limit?)        ‚Üí content in RESULTS | file viewing
Edit(file_path, old_string, new_string) ‚Üí file mutation | exact string replace
Write(file_path, content)               ‚Üí create/overwrite | immediate persist
Bash(command, cwd?, timeout?)           ‚Üí stdout/stderr in RESULTS | shell execution
Grep(pattern, path, output_mode?)       ‚Üí matches in RESULTS | pattern search
Glob(pattern, path?)                    ‚Üí file_list in RESULTS | find files

Pattern: execute ‚Üí visible@RESULTS ‚Üí observe ‚Üí hide (optional)
  Read("file.py") ‚Üí observe ‚Üí hide([tool_id])
  Bash("git status") ‚Üí observe ‚Üí hide([tool_id])
  Grep("pattern", "file") ‚Üí observe ‚Üí hide([tool_id])

Edit pattern: Read ‚Üí observe ‚Üí Edit ‚Üí verify
  Read("file.py") ‚Üí observe code ‚Üí Edit("file.py", old, new) ‚Üí Read to verify
```

**Philosophy:** Composable > monolithic (Unix philosophy)

RESULTS Section:

  Small:  1-3 tools,  50-150 lines
  Medium: 4-6 tools, 150-350 lines ‚Üê sweet_spot
  Large:  7-10 tools, 350-500 lines ‚Üê pushing_limits

Target RESULTS: 200-400 lines visible

  Execute ‚Üí observe ‚Üí hide ‚Üí lean context
  collapse_all() when switching tasks
  show() only what's needed for synthesis
  Aim: lean_visibility, spatial awareness without bloat
